title: Case Study
text: Shi et al. studied transcription factors microRNA co-regulation genes involved gastric cancer reveal signaling pathways drive development disease (Shi et al., 2015). Briefly, used previous literature microarrays identify differentially expressed transcription factors (TF) microRNAs gastric cancer tissues compared normal ones. , identified target genes using annotation databases constructed TF-microRNA gene regulatory network. Finally, identified hub-genes performed functional analysis namely KEGG pathways enrichment find signalling pathways belong . , tried tackling question using cRegulome data. started point like PLOS paper using lists differentially expressed TF microRNAs, used cRegulome data find driving genes pathways Stomach esophageal cancer (STES).

title: Case Study
text: started obtaining lists differentially expressed TFs microRNAs compiled previous literature microarray profiling respectively. numbers first entries lists:
code: library(cRegulome) library(readxl) library(ggplot2) library(RSQLite) library(R.utils) library(igraph) library(AnnotationDbi) library(org.Hs.eg.db) library(clusterProfiler) # list of transcription factors if(!file.exists('tf.xlsx'))      download.file('https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4393113/bin/pone.0122882.s001.xlsx',                   destfile = 'tf.xlsx', mode = 'wb') tf <- read_excel('tf.xlsx', skip = 1)  # list of microRNAs if(!file.exists('mir.xls'))      download.file('https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4393113/bin/pone.0122882.s003.xls',                   destfile = 'mir.xls', mode = 'wb') mir <- read_excel('mir.xls', skip = 1) length(unique(tf$SOURCE)); unique(tf$SOURCE) # TFs ## [1] 5 ## [1] "TFAP2A" "ETV4"   "LEF1"   "MYB"    "MYBL2" length(unique(mir$AccID)); head(unique(mir$AccID), 5) # microRNAs ## [1] 93 ## [1] "hsa-miR-18b*"   "hsa-miR-409-3p" "hsa-let-7g"     "hsa-miR-30c"    ## [5] "hsa-miR-30a"

what: Use cRegulome to access correlation data
title: Case Study
text: , show straight forward way obtaining correlation/co-expression data using cRegulome package. two simple steps. First, download database using package first time. make query using TF/microRNAs interest limit output known targets. convenience, data included test subset database file used throughout vignette instead full database file. comparison numbers found TF/microRNAs previous lists query output.
code: # download the db file when using it for the first time destfile = paste(tempdir(), 'cRegulome.db.gz', sep = '/') if(!file.exists(destfile)) {     get_db(test = TRUE) }  # connect to the db file db_file = paste(tempdir(), 'cRegulome.db', sep = '/') conn <- dbConnect(SQLite(), db_file) # query the database creg_tf <- get_tf(conn,                   tf = unique(tf$SOURCE),                   study = 'STES',                   targets_only = TRUE)  creg_mir <- get_mir(conn,                     mir = tolower(unique(mir$AccID)),                     study = 'STES',                     targets_only = TRUE) length(unique(creg_mir$mirna_base) %in% unique(tolower(mir$AccID))) ## [1] 34 length(unique(creg_tf$tf) %in% unique(tf$SOURCE)) ## [1] 4

title: Case Study
text: purpose constructing network, decided limit nodes TFs/microRNAs gene targets high correlation (absolute Pearson’s correlation > 0.3). first return cRegulome query database tweak output used igraph package build network. First, construct two separate networks TF microRNA correlations using cor_igraph function. , combine two networks attributes.
code: # query cRegulome to get high correlated targets creg_tf <- get_tf(conn,                   tf = unique(tf$SOURCE),                   study = 'STES',                   min_abs_cor = .3,                   targets_only = TRUE) creg_mir <- get_mir(conn,                     mir = tolower(unique(mir$AccID)),                     study = 'STES',                     min_abs_cor = .3,                     targets_only = TRUE) # make two separate networks p1 <- cor_igraph(cTF(creg_tf)) p2 <- cor_igraph(cmicroRNA(creg_mir))  # combine networks p <- graph.union(p1, p2)  # combine attributes V(p)$type[V(p)$name %in% unique(creg_tf$tf)] <- 'TF' V(p)$type[V(p)$name %in% unique(creg_mir$mirna_base)] <- 'microRNA' V(p)$type[is.na(V(p)$type)] <- 'gene'  V(p)$color <- c('lightgreen', 'blue', 'red')[factor(V(p)$type)]  V(p)$label <- ifelse(V(p)$type == 'gene', '', V(p)$name)  E(p)$weight_1[is.na(E(p)$weight_1)] <- E(p)$weight_2[!is.na(E(p)$weight_2)]

title: Case Study
text: Simple useful information network can obtained analyzing vertices degree. node degree number edges shares nodes graph. nodes network constructed edge/connection another node. gene nodes one edge genes 2 5 edges. ones regulated two regulatory element (TF/microRNAs).  Visualizing dense network may provide lot details, however notice transcription factors (red) microRNAs (blue) many cases co-regulate one gene. following section, used clustering algorithm capture connections sub-communities used KEGG enrichment analysis ask whether biologically meaningful.
code: par(mfrow=c(1,2)) deg <- degree(p)  # full network degrees plot(density(deg),       main = 'Full network degrees')  # gene degrees plot(density(deg[V(p)$type == 'gene']),      main = 'Gene nodes degrees') # plot network set.seed(123) par(mfrow=c(1,1)) new_p <- delete.vertices(p, deg < 2) deg <- degree(new_p) plot(new_p,      vertex.size = log2(deg)+1,      vertex.label.dist = .3,      vertex.label.cex   = .8,      vertex.label = V(new_p)$label,      edge.arrow.size = 0)  legend('bottomleft',        legend = unique(V(new_p)$type),        col = unique(V(new_p)$color),        pch = 19)

title: Case Study
text: KEGG pathways enrichment analysis applied 5 clusters separately. Clusters 3 4 resulted enrichment 4 10 KEGG pathways respectively. significant enrichment found 3 clusters.
code: # prepare entrez ids entrez <- lapply(clusters, function(x) {     ei <- AnnotationDbi::select(org.Hs.eg.db, x, 'ENTREZID', 'SYMBOL')$ENTREZID     na.omit(ei) })  # run kegg enrichment comp_path <- compareCluster(entrez, fun = 'enrichKEGG', organism = 'hsa') comp_path@compareClusterResult %>%     ggplot(aes(x = Description, y = Count)) +     geom_col() +     facet_wrap(~Cluster, scales = 'free_y', ncol = 1) +     coord_flip() +     labs(x = '')

title: Using cRegulome
text: Transcription factors microRNAs important regulating gene expression normal physiology pathological conditions. Many bioinformatic tools built predict identify transcription factors microRNA targets role development diseases including cancers. availability public access high-throughput data allowed data-driven discoveries validations predictions. , build kind tools integrative analyses provide tool access, manage visualize data open source databases. cRegulome provides programmatic access regulome (microRNA transcription factor) correlations target genes cancer. package obtains local instance Cistrome Cancer miRCancerdb databases provides objects methods interact visualize correlation data.

title: Using cRegulome
text: get started cRegulome, show quick example. first start downloading small test database file, make simple query convert output cRegulome object print visualize.
code: # load required libraries library(cRegulome) library(RSQLite) library(ggplot2) # download the db file when using it for the first time destfile = paste(tempdir(), 'cRegulome.db.gz', sep = '/') if(!file.exists(destfile)) {     get_db(test = TRUE) }  # connect to the db file db_file = paste(tempdir(), 'cRegulome.db', sep = '/') conn <- dbConnect(SQLite(), db_file) # alternative to downloading the database file wget https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/pfigshare-u-files/9537385/cRegulome.db.gz gunzip cRegulome.db.gz # enter a custom query with different arguments dat <- get_mir(conn,                mir = 'hsa-let-7g',                study = 'STES',                min_abs_cor = .3,                max_num = 5)  # make a cmicroRNA object    ob <- cmicroRNA(dat) # print object ob ## A cmicroRNA object: microRNA-gene correlations in Cancer ##  Contains: ##  1 Cancer study/ies: STES  ##  1 microRNA/s: hsa-let-7g  ##  5 features: ARHGEF15 LSM11 STARD13 CXorf36 IL13 # plot object cor_plot(ob)

title: Using cRegulome
text: two main sources data used package Cistrome Cancer miRCancerdb databases. Cistrome Cancer based integrative analysis Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) public ChIP-seq data. provides calculated correlations (n = 320) transcription factors target genes (n = 29) cancer study. addition, Cistrome Cancer provides transcription factors regulatory potential target non-target genes. miRCancerdb uses TCGA data TargetScan annotations correlate known microRNAs (n = 750) target non-target genes (n = 25) cancer studies.

title: Using cRegulome
text: cRegulome obtains pre-build SQLite database file Cistrome Cancer miRCancerdb databases. details build provided cRegulomedb addition scripts used pull, format deposit data -line repository. Briefly, SQLite database consist 4 tables cor_mir cor_tf correlation values targets_mir targets_tf microRNA miRBase ID transcription factors symbols genes mappings. Two indices created facilitate database search using miRBase IDs transcription factors symbols. database file can downloaded using function get_db. show details database file, following code connects database show names tables fields .
code: # table names tabs <- dbListTables(conn) print(tabs) ## [1] "cor_mir"     "cor_tf"      "targets_mir" "targets_tf" # fields/columns in the tables for(i in seq_along(tabs)) {   print(dbListFields(conn, tabs[i])) } ## [1] "mirna_base" "feature"    "STES"       ## [1] "tf"      "feature" "STES"    ## [1] "mirna_base" "feature"    ## [1] "tf"      "feature" "study"

title: Using cRegulome
text: query database using cRegulome, provide two main functions; get_mir get_tf querying microRNA transcription factors correlations respectively. Users need provide proper IDs microRNA, transcription factor symbols /TCGA study identifiers. microRNAs referred official miRBase IDs, transcription factors corresponding official gene symbols contains TCGA studies common identifiers. either cases, output calling functions tidy data frame 4 columns; mirna_base/ tf, feature, cor study correspond miRBase IDs transcription factors symbol, gene symbol, correlation value TCGA study identifier. show example query. , illustrate query executed database using basic RSQLite dbplyr get_* functions .
code: # query the db for two microRNAs dat_mir <- get_mir(conn,                    mir = c('hsa-let-7g', 'hsa-let-7i'),                    study = 'STES')  # query the db for two transcription factors dat_tf <- get_tf(conn,                  tf = c('LEF1', 'MYB'),                  study = 'STES')  # show first 6 line of each of the data.frames head(dat_mir); head(dat_tf) ##   mirna_base feature   cor study ## 1 hsa-let-7g    ABL2  0.11  STES ## 2 hsa-let-7g  ACTR10 -0.16  STES ## 3 hsa-let-7g  ACVR1C -0.13  STES ## 4 hsa-let-7g ADAMTS1  0.27  STES ## 5 hsa-let-7g ADAMTS5  0.20  STES ## 6 hsa-let-7g   ADCY9  0.18  STES ##     tf feature  cor study ## 1 LEF1     A2M 0.55  STES ## 2 LEF1  A4GALT 0.40  STES ## 3 LEF1   ABCA1 0.44  STES ## 4 LEF1   ABCA6 0.54  STES ## 5 LEF1   ABCA8 0.41  STES ## 6 LEF1   ABCA9 0.48  STES

title: Using cRegulome
text: Two S3 objects provided cRegulome store dispatch methods correlation data. cmicroRNA cTF microRNA transcription factors respectively. structure objects similar. Basically, S3 objects, ’s list 4 items; microRNA TF regulome element, features gene hits, studies TCGA studies finally corr either data.frame object data.single TCGA study named list data.frames data multiple studies. data.frames regulome element (microRNAs transcription factors) columns features/genes rows. construct objects, users need call constructor function corresponding names data.frame output form get_*. reverse possible calling function cor_tidy object get back tidy data.frame.
code: # explore the cmicroRNA object ob_mir <- cmicroRNA(dat_mir) class(ob_mir) ## [1] "cmicroRNA" str(ob_mir) ## List of 4 ##  $ microRNA: chr [1:2] "hsa-let-7g" "hsa-let-7i" ##  $ features: chr [1:612] "ABL2" "ACTR10" "ACVR1C" "ADAMTS1" ... ##  $ studies : chr "STES" ##  $ corr    :List of 1 ##   ..$ STES:'data.frame': 612 obs. of  2 variables: ##   .. ..$ hsa-let-7g: num [1:612] NA NA NA NA 0.11 NA NA NA -0.16 NA ... ##   .. ..$ hsa-let-7i: num [1:612] -0.2 0.12 0.14 -0.1 0.27 -0.12 0.13 0.1 NA 0.23 ... ##  - attr(*, "class")= chr "cmicroRNA" # explore the cTF object ob_tf <- cTF(dat_tf) class(ob_tf) ## [1] "cTF" str(ob_tf) ## List of 4 ##  $ TF      : chr [1:2] "LEF1" "MYB" ##  $ features: chr [1:1953] "A2M" "A4GALT" "ABCA1" "ABCA6" ... ##  $ studies : chr "STES" ##  $ corr    :List of 1 ##   ..$ STES:'data.frame': 1953 obs. of  2 variables: ##   .. ..$ LEF1: num [1:1953] 0.55 0.4 0.44 0.54 0.41 0.48 0.56 0.43 0.54 0.45 ... ##   .. ..$ MYB : num [1:1953] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ... ##  - attr(*, "class")= chr "cTF"

title: Obtain and Visualize Regulome-Gene Expression Correlations in Cancer
text: get starting cRegulome show quick example. first start downloading small test database file, make simple query convert output cRegulome object print visualize. {r load_libraries} # load required libraries library(cRegulome) library(RSQLite) library(ggplot2) access test set file package directly
code: # install the package from CRAN install.packages('cRegulome') # install the development version from github devtools::install_github('ropensci/cRegulome')  # install the development version and build vignette from github  devtools::install_github('ropensci/cRegulome', build_vignettes = TRUE) if(!file.exists('cRegulome.db')) {     get_db(test = TRUE) }  # connect to the db file conn <- dbConnect(SQLite(), 'cRegulome.db') # locate the testset file and connect fl <- system.file('extdata', 'cRegulome.db', package = 'cRegulome') conn <- dbConnect(SQLite(), fl) # enter a custom query with different arguments dat <- get_mir(conn,                mir = 'hsa-let-7g',                study = 'STES',                min_abs_cor = .3,                max_num = 5)  # make a cmicroRNA object    ob <- cmicroRNA(dat) # print object ob

title: Get cRegulome.db file — get_db
text: function calls download.file download pre-build database file cRegulome. Additionally, function checks validity pre-defined URL whether database file exists current working directory avoid redownloading . Typically, users run function first time use package update database latest version.

title: Get cRegulome.db file — get_db
code: get_db(test = FALSE, destfile, ...)

title: Get cRegulome.db file — get_db
text: test logical, default FALSE. TRUE downloads database file structure subset data speed. destfile character vector desired path database  file. default, specified, constructed using  tempdir directory string cRegulome.db.gz ... Optional arguments passed download.file

title: Get cRegulome.db file — get_db
text: Downloads compressed sqlite file current working directory. file named cRegulome.db.gz default advised change name avoid breaking functions calls database.

what: Get microRNA correlations from cRegulome.db — get_mir
title: Get microRNA correlations from cRegulome.db — get_mir
text: function access sqlite database file obtained running get_db. Basically, function provides ways query  database correlation data microRNAs interest. function  returns error database file cRegulome.db  working directory.

title: Get microRNA correlations from cRegulome.db — get_mir
code: get_mir(conn, mir, study, min_abs_cor, max_num, targets_only = FALSE, targets)

title: Get microRNA correlations from cRegulome.db — get_mir
text: conn connection returned  dbConnect mir required character vector microRNAs interest. miRBase ID official identifiers widely used miRBase database, http://www.mirbase.org/. study character vector Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) study identifiers. view available studies TCGA project, https://tcga-data.nci.nih.gov/docs/publications/tcga. left default NULL available studies included. min_abs_cor numeric, absolute correlation minimum 0 1 mir. max_num integer, maximum number features show mir study. targets_only logical whether restrict output  recognized target features. targets character vector gene symbol names.

title: Get microRNA correlations from cRegulome.db — get_mir
text: tidy data.frame four columns. mirna_base microRNA miRBase IDs, feature features/genes, cor corresponding expression correlations study TCGA study ID.

what: Get transcription factor correlations from cRegulome.db — get_tf
title: Get transcription factor correlations from cRegulome.db — get_tf
text: function access sqlite database file obtained running get_db. Basically, function provides ways query  database correlation data transcription factors interest.  function returns error database file cRegulome.db  working directory.

title: Get transcription factor correlations from cRegulome.db — get_tf
code: get_tf(conn, tf, study, min_abs_cor, max_num, targets_only = FALSE, targets)

title: Get transcription factor correlations from cRegulome.db — get_tf
text: conn connection returned  dbConnect tf required character vector transcription factor interest. HUGO official gene symbols genes contains transcription factor. study character vector Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) study identifiers. view available studies TCGA project, https://tcga-data.nci.nih.gov/docs/publications/tcga. left default NULL available studies included. min_abs_cor numeric, absolute correlation minimum 0 1 mir. max_num integer, maximum number features show mir study. targets_only logical whether restrict output  recognized target features. targets character vector gene symbol names.

title: Get transcription factor correlations from cRegulome.db — get_tf
text: tidy data.frame four columns. tf official gene symbols genes contains transcription factor, feature features/genes, cor corresponding expression correlations study TCGA study ID.

title: Get transcription factor correlations from cRegulome.db — get_tf
